abstract: Hong Kong Journal; government, facing space crunch and rising death rate, is struggling to convince residents to engage in 'green burials,' cremation and the scattering of ashes instead of traditional burials or the storage of cremation urns in elaborate buildings; opponents of efforts to build gardens for scattering ashes fear everything from ghosts of disrespected loved ones to decline in property values.
lead_paragraph: Concerned by a scarcity of burial space and a rise in deaths, Hong Kong officials are urging the public to scatter ashes in designated gardens or at sea.

headline.main: Hong Kong’s Drive for ‘Green Burials’ Clashes With Tradition
headline.print_headline: Trying to Redefine Final Resting Place

snippet: Concerned by a scarcity of burial space and a rise in deaths, Hong Kong officials are urging the public to scatter ashes in designated gardens or at sea.
